document.masterDocTitle: Turritellidae (Gastropoda) of the Miocene Paratethys Sea with considerations about turritellid genera

paragraph.materialsCitation: Holotype Nr. 2906, Bayerisches Geologisches Landesamt , Munich , Germany ; Kaltenbachgraben , Bavaria , Germany ; early Miocene , Eggenburgian.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Studied material. 3 spec. NHMW 1872/0020/0195, Kaltenbachgraben ( Germany ); 1 spec. NHMW 2018/0166/0001, 6 spec. NHMW 1860/0050/0268, 1spec. NHMW 1912/0001/0012 ( holotype of
Turritella terebralis eggenburgensis Sieber 1960
; illustrated in Schaffer 1912 , pl. 52, fig. 15), 1 spec. NHMW 1912/0001/0013 (illustrated in Schaffer 1912 , pl. 52, fig. 16), Nondorf ( Austria ); 6 spec. NHMW 1860/0050/0254, Mold ( Austria ); 10 spec. NHMW 1934/0001/0080, 5 spec. NHMW 2018/0167/0001, (including specimens illustrated by Schaffer 1912 , pl. 52, figs 17–19), Maria Dreieichen ( Austria ); 1 spec. NHMW 1963/0259/0000, Gauderndorf ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 2, fig.1); 6 spec. NHMW 1845/0015, 0048, Loibersdorf ( Austria ).

Illustrated material. Figs 8A
1–2
: Nondorf ( Austria ): SL: 119.3 mm , MD: 29.1 mm , NHMW 1912/0001/0013; Figs 8B
1–2
: Nondorf ( Austria ): SL: 118.6 mm , MD: 35.1 mm , NHMW 1912/0001/0012; Figs 8C
1 – 2
: Nondorf ( Austria ): SL: 101.5 mm , MD: 30.6 mm NHMW 1860/0050/0268. Fig. 9A : Mörtersdorf ( Austria ): several specimens on sediment, NHMW 2018/0165/0001 (note that specimen A 1 represents
Peyrotia desmarestina
).

Revised description. Shell large, solid, moderately slender. Protoconch and earliest teleoconch whorls unknown. Teleoconch comprising at least 16 whorls; early whorls frustate, bicarinate with prominent B and C spiral cords; angulation coinciding with C cord. Flat to weakly convex sutural ramp with 4 – 5 prominent secondary spiral cords. Whorl profile weakly convex below angulation bearing 1 – 2 secondary spiral cords. Whorl profile soon becoming convex with periphery in abapical third of whorl; periphery sometimes angulated even in late teleoconch whorls. Adapical part of whorl weakly convex or rarely nearly flat. C spiral cord usually more prominent throughout growth accompanied by 7 – 9 broad spiral cords of rectangular cross-section, separated by narrower interspaces. Spiral sculpture fading out on last teleoconch whorls. Lateral sinus with steep angle, very wide, deep, simple, regularly concave, LS p distinctly abapical, without sigmoidal part in adapical half. Basal sinus straight to moderately prosocyrt. Aperture thin, subcircular; inner lip narrowly reflected passing into thin glossy, sheet-like parietal callus. No inner lirae present.

Shell measurements and ratios. Complete specimens are rare; largest nearly complete specimen: SL = 119.3 mm , MD = 29.1 mm . n = 5 adult specimens: AA: μ = 19.4° (σ = 1.67°), PA: μ = 15.8° (σ = 1.1°). Lateral sinus (n = 5): LS angle = 26.5° (σ = 3.7°), LS p = 1.4 (σ = 0.21), LS d = 3.2 (σ = 0.36).

Discussion. The Paratethyan specimens differ from the largest French shells of
Turritella terebralis
in their smaller size (corresponding to the height of the last whorl of the Atlantic specimens) and in the much broader and rectangular spiral cords. Even specimens of
Turritella terebralis
s. s. with prominent sculpture, from Léognan and Saucats ( France ), display a much more delicate sculpture on early teleoconch whorls and the spiral cords are more or less trigonal in cross-section ( Figs 8D
1 –D
2 ,
SL: 128.2 mm , MD: 39.3 mm Léognan ( France ), NHMW 1850/0018/0100). Typical specimens of
T. terebralis
from the Burdigalian of the Torino Hills (NHMW 1862/0035/0463) agree in sculpture with those from France and lack prominent spiral sculpture. Therefore, it seems to be justified to separate the Paratethyan populations from typical Miocene northeastern Atlantic
Turritella terebralis Lamarck, 1822
. Schaffer (1912) compared the Paratethyan shells with T. t. percingulellata Sacco, 1895 , from the Burdigalian of the Torino Hills. The spiral cords of this Italian morphotype, however, are narrower and Sacco (1895) compared its sculpture with that of
Turritella venus d’Orbigny, 1852
. This sculpture type is also seen in
Turritella terebralis sulcata Dollfus, Cotter & Gomes, 1903
and
Turritella terebralis lusitanica Zbyszewski, 1957
from the early Miocene of Portugal . For the Paratethyan shells, Hölzl (1958) introduced
Turritella terebralis innaequicingulata
as variation name based on specimens from the Eggenburgian of Bavaria [note that innaequicingulata is a typographical error for
inaequicingulata
, which was correctly used by Hölzl (1958) several times in the discussion and the plate caption. Therefore, we emend the incorrect original name]. Later, Sieber (1960) introduced
Turritella terebralis eggenburgensis
as a subjective junior synonym of
T. t. inaequicingulata
for specimens from the Eggenburg region in Austria . The prominent sculpture of the early spire is somewhat variable concerning width of spiral cords and their interspaces but a separation of these always co-occurring morphotypes as biological subspecies is surely unjustified.

Turritella inaequicingulata
is a very characteristic species, which is restricted in the Paratethys to the early and middle Eggenburgian (early Burdigalian). It disappeared already during the late Eggenburgian and is unknown from Ottnangian strata. During the Karpatian (late Burdigalian) it was already fully replaced by
Turritella gradata Menke in Hörnes, 1855
.

Paleoenvironment.
Turritella inaequicingulata
is found in large numbers, forming “turritelline-dominated assemblages” ( Allmon & Knight 1993 ) in the Loibersdorf Formation in the Eggenburg area ( Fig. 9A ); the depositional environment represents shallow sublittoral settings (
Mandic et al . 2004b
).

paragraph.emphasis:
Distribution of
Turritella terebralis Lamarck, 1822
s. l.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Numerous subspecies names have been proposed for various morphotypes of
Turritella terebralis
; e.g. grata, aquensis, aturensis and fragilis for French specimens by Cossmann & Peyrot (1922) , subgradata, turritissima , subagibbosa and percingulellata for Italian specimens by Sacco, 1895 ,
sulcata
and lusitanica for Portuguese specimens by
Dollfus et al . (1903)
and Zbyszewski (1957) . We have not seen the types of these ‘species’ and cannot evaluate if
Turritella terebralis
s. l. consist of distinct (sub)species with paleogeographic and/or stratigraphic significance (as proposed herein at least for the Paratethyan populations).
Turritella terebralis
s. s. is most probably restricted to the Aquitanian and Burdigalian of the northeastern Atlantic.
Turritella terebralis
s. l. , however, has a much wider geographic distribution:

non in tropical eastern Atlantic . Böhm (1913) recorded
Turritella terebralis sulcata Dollfus, Cotter & Gomes, 1903
and T. t.
applanata Böhm, 1913
from the early? Miocene of Angola . Although the lateral sinus of the West African species agrees with that of
Turritella terebralis
s. l. , it differs in its deeply incised suture and high last whorl and is overall rather slender compared to
T. terebralis
. Later,
Dartevelle et al . (1954)
and Brébion (1983) reported
Turritella terebralis
again from the Burdigalian of Angola . The illustrated specimen of
Dartevelle et al . (1954)
does not allow a clear identification, but it most probably also represents
T. applanata
.
Turritella applanata Böhm
seems to be more closely related to the extant West African
T. ungulina ( Linnaeus, 1758 )
and
T. ligar Deshayes, 1843
than to the Miocene
T. terebralis
.
